<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_pool_try_alloc:
```c
void *
MHD_pool_try_alloc (struct MemoryPool *pool,
                    size_t size,
                    size_t *required_bytes)
{
  void *ret;
  size_t asize;

  mhd_assert (pool->end >= pool->pos);
  mhd_assert (pool->size >= pool->end - pool->pos);
  mhd_assert (pool->pos == ROUND_TO_ALIGN (pool->pos));
  asize = ROUND_TO_ALIGN_PLUS_RED_ZONE (size);
  if ( (0 == asize) && (0 != size) )
  { /* size is too close to SIZE_MAX, very unlikely */
    *required_bytes = SIZE_MAX;
    return NULL;
  }
  if (asize > pool->end - pool->pos)
  {
    mhd_assert ((pool->end - pool->pos) == \
                ROUND_TO_ALIGN (pool->end - pool->pos));
    if (asize <= pool->end)
      *required_bytes = asize - (pool->end - pool->pos);
    else
      *required_bytes = SIZE_MAX;
    return NULL;
  }
  *required_bytes = 0;
  ret = &pool->memory[pool->end - asize];
  pool->end -= asize;
  _MHD_UNPOISON_MEMORY (ret, size);
  return ret;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No suspicious fragments found. All pointer usages in this function require non-const qualification for legitimate reasons:
- Parameter 'struct MemoryPool *pool' is modified (pool->end is changed), so it cannot be a pointer-to-const.
- Parameter 'size_t *required_bytes' is an output parameter that is written in several branches, so it cannot be a pointer-to-const.
- The local 'void *ret' is returned as a pointer to writable memory obtained from pool->memory; the buffer is intended for use as mutable storage, so it must be non-const. The call to _MHD_UNPOISON_MEMORY(ret, size) also implies writable memory.
- There are no other pointer variables or pointer-to-object expressions in this function that are only read and could be changed to point-to-const.
Given the above, Rule 8.13 (prefer const-qualified pointee types where possible) does not indicate any change for this function: each pointer currently points to a non-const object because the code either modifies the pointee or returns writable memory. Therefore no fragments need further investigation for this rule.
